ygData.subject: Re: [rest-discuss] Re: REST Transaction Process
ygData.msgSnippet: [we can stay offlist unless someone else cares about this issue] REST s hidden representations mean that only the server can implement isolation (because only

Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] Re: REST Transaction Process
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=4849001
X-Yahoo-Profile: shop2it

[we can stay offlist unless someone else cares
about this issue]

REST's hidden representations mean that only the
server can implement isolation (because only it
can model the effects of transactional
POST/PUT/DELETEs on resources).

So we can't be talking about a transaction agent
other than the server and the context here is an
unmediated GET to that server with some
transaction-id header in the request.

The significance of this GET with a transaction-id
header is to cause the transaction to fail if the
GET resource is modified before the transaction
concludes.

Note: If some other prior operation made the
transaction dependent on the resource then the GET
becomes safe, but the GET itself should not have
that effect.

-Alex-

_________________________________________________________________
S. Alexander Jacobson                  mailto:me@...
tel:917-770-6565                       http://alexjacobson.com


On Thu, 19 Feb 2004, Walden Mathews wrote:

> Alex,
>
> I need to set up a work account to reply on list, and
> I'm a little lazy...
>
> Since you're quoting RFC 2616, please take it literally.
> The GET method is not having any significance other
> than retrieval in your example.  Your transaction agent
> is having that significance on its own initiative. GET is
> still safe.  What your agent does with the result is another
> matter; has to be, otherwise, anytime I GET content
> from one resource to POST to another, in your eyes
> the GET is not safe.  Do you believe that?
>
> Walden
>
>
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: "S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
> To: "Walden Mathews" <wmathews@...>
> Sent: Thursday, February 19, 2004 10:40 AM
> Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] Re: REST Transaction Process
>
>
> | I don't know if you wanted to reply on list,
> | but...
> |
> | RFC 2616:
> | "In particular, the convention has been established that the GET and
> | HEAD methods SHOULD NOT have the significance of taking an action
> | other than retrieval."
> |
> | So in this transaction:
> |
> |   OPEN TRANSACTION
> |   LOTS OF WORK
> |   GET URI1
> |   MORE WORK
> |   CLOSE TRANSACTION
> |
> | The GET has the significance of causing the
> | transaction to fail.  Transaction failure is
> | different from retrieval.  So Transactional GET is
> | NOT safe.
> |
> | Note: On rereading the definition in the RFC, it
> | is, however, idempotent.  I stand corrected on
> | that front.
> |
> | -Alex-
> |
> |
> | On Thu, 19 Feb 2004, Walden Mathews wrote:
> |
> | > Alex,
> | >
> | > The assertion "GET is safe" does not address the
> | > phenomenon you observed below.
> | >
> | > Safety and idempotence are properties of the method
> | > as measured through changes to the resource to which
> | > the method is applied.
> | >
> | > In your example the resource at URI1 may be changing
> | > during the transaction, but it is not being changed by
> | > the GET operation, and that's all that matters in
> | > determining whether or not GET is safe.
> | >
> | > Walden
> | >
> | > ----- Original Message -----
> | > From: "S. Alexander Jacobson" <alex@...>
> | > To: "Walden Mathews" <waldenm@...>
> | > Cc: "rest-discuss" <rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com>
> | > Sent: Thursday, February 19, 2004 1:40 AM
> | > Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] Re: REST Transaction Process
> | >
> | >
> | > | If you have isolation, GET on a public resource
> | > | (within the scope of the transaction) changes the
> | > | state of the transaction because whether the
> | > | transaction closes now depends on whether the GET
> | > | resource is modified before the subsequent COMMIT.
> | > | For example:
> | > |
> | > |   GET URI1
> | > |   OPEN TRANSACTION
> | > |   GET URI1
> | > |   PUT URI2 VALUE
> | > |   PUT URI3 VALUE
> | > |   COMMIT
> | > |
> | > | The first GET has no effect on the outcome of the
> | > | transtion.  The second GET changes the state of
> | > | the transaction.  In particular, the result of the
> | > | GET is that the transaction may fail may cause the
> | > | subsequent sequence of actions to fail (if URI1
> | > | changes before the second PUT).
> | > |
> | > | Note: You want this transaction to fail because
> | > | perhaps VALUE is computed from the content of
> | > | URI1 (e.g. you are incrementing the value of
> | > | something).
> | > |
> | > | -Alex-
> | > |
> | > | _________________________________________________________________
> | > | S. Alexander Jacobson                  mailto:me@...
> | > | tel:917-770-6565                       http://alexjacobson.com
> | > |
> | > |
> | > | On Wed, 18 Feb 2004, Walden Mathews wrote:
> | > |
> | > | > Alex,
> | > | >
> | > | > :   b. it is okay for GETs with these transaction-id
> | > | > :      headers to have side-effects (subsequently causing
> | > | > :      the transaction to fail if the resource is changed
> | > | > :      before the transaction completes)
> | > | > :      Note: I may be misinterpreting this claim.
> | > | > :      You may have been arguing c...
> | > | > :
> | > | >
> | > | > I've been wondering for some time what you mean
> | > | > by this, and I'm still not sure I follow.  Are you saying
> | > | > that the GET itself induces a state change in the
> | > | > resource it was applied to?  Or are you saying that
> | > | > an agent uses GET to decide whether to change
> | > | > some other resource (in this case, a transaction, as
> | > | > in commit or rollback)?
> | > | >
> | > | > If it's the latter, then you're not really talking about
> | > | > a property of the GET, and so no rules appear to be
> | > | > broken.
> | > | >
> | > | > If it's the former, I don't see how.
> | > | >
> | > | > Walden
> | > | >
> | > | >
